articles.headline: 4 Madoffs Being Sued for Millions
articles.snippet: The complaint does not accuse the family members of participating in the Ponzi scheme, but it calls them “derelict” in carrying out their professional duties.
articles.abstract: The complaint does not accuse the family members of participating in the Ponzi scheme, but it calls them “derelict” in carrying out their professional duties.
articles.lead_paragraph: For months, the luxurious life once enjoyed by Bernard L. Madoff’s family was a bitter pill for the thousands of victims who lost their own wealth and comforts in his long-running Ponzi scheme.

articles.headline: The High Price of Being a Gay Couple
articles.snippet: From health care and pensions to family planning, life is more expensive for same-sex couples.
articles.abstract: From health care and pensions to family planning, life is more expensive for same-sex couples.
articles.lead_paragraph: Much of the debate over legalizing gay marriage has focused on God and Scripture, the Constitution and equal protection.
articles.byline: By Tara Siegel Bernard and Ron Lieber

articles.headline: Retailers Expect Flat Christmas Sales This Year
articles.snippet: The retailing industry, which posted a sales decline of about 2 percent last Christmas season, expects the same this year.
articles.abstract: The retailing industry, which posted a sales decline of about 2 percent last Christmas season, expects the same this year.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the retail business, it is never too early to think about Christmas. So a lot of people are thinking about it, and taking surveys to test the mood of the American consumer, and deciding that this Christmas will be as bad as last  which is to say, one of the worst on record.

articles.headline: Guinea Seethes as a Captain Rules at Gunpoint
articles.snippet: Capt. Moussa Dadis Camara gave some people hope when he seized power in December, but that optimism is gone.
articles.abstract: Capt. Moussa Dadis Camara gave some people hope when he seized power in December, but that optimism is gone.
articles.lead_paragraph: CONAKRY, Guinea  At the military camp where he makes decisions  he does not care for government buildings  the captain who is president explained why he did not get to the political rally earlier this week that his soldiers turned into a bloodbath.

articles.headline: Report Cites Firefight as Lesson on Afghan War
articles.snippet: A 2008 firefight in eastern Afghanistan has become a template for how not to win there, and helps to explain the strategy of Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal, the new commander.
articles.abstract: A 2008 firefight in eastern Afghanistan has become a template for how not to win there, and helps to explain the strategy of Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal, the new commander.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The paratroopers of Chosen Company had plenty to worry about as they began digging in at their new outpost on the fringe of a hostile frontier village in eastern Afghanistan.

articles.headline: Incompetent? No, Just Not a Leader
articles.snippet: Unlike his legendary predecessor at Bank of America, Ken Lewis turned out not to be a born leader.
articles.abstract: Unlike his legendary predecessor at Bank of America, Ken Lewis turned out not to be a born leader.
articles.lead_paragraph: Some people are born to be leaders.

articles.headline: Scarcity of King Salmon Hurt Alaskan Fishermen
articles.snippet: Until recently, king salmon was a major source of income and food in villages along the Yukon River. What has led to its scarcity is not well understood.
articles.abstract: Until recently, king salmon was a major source of income and food in villages along the Yukon River. What has led to its scarcity is not well understood.
articles.lead_paragraph: MARSHALL, Alaska  Just a few years ago, king salmon played an outsize role in villages along the Yukon River. Fishing provided meaningful income, fed families throughout the year, and kept alive long-held traditions of Yup’ik Eskimos and Athabascan Indians.

articles.headline: President of Toyota Apologizes
articles.snippet: Toyota has suffered a series of adverse events since Akio Toyoda became president of the company a few months ago, and he apologized for them.
articles.abstract: Toyota has suffered a series of adverse events since Akio Toyoda became president of the company a few months ago, and he apologized for them.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO  Even by Japanese standards  where chief executives routinely make public apologies if their company is in crisis  Akio Toyoda’s comments on Friday were surprising.
articles.byline: By Hiroko Tabuchi and Micheline Maynard

articles.headline: Offshore Haven Considers a Heresy: Taxation
articles.snippet: With shrinking revenue and high public spending, the Cayman Islands might have to raise taxes.
articles.abstract: With shrinking revenue and high public spending, the Cayman Islands might have to raise taxes.
articles.lead_paragraph: GEORGE TOWN, Cayman Islands  What happens to a tax haven when it has to raise taxes? The Cayman Islands may soon find out.

articles.headline: Detainee’s Case Illustrates Bind of Prison’s Fate
articles.snippet: To understand how hard it is to close Guantánamo, consider the case of Alla Ali Bin Ali Ahmed of Yemen.
articles.abstract: To understand how hard it is to close Guantánamo, consider the case of Alla Ali Bin Ali Ahmed of Yemen.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  To understand how hard it is proving for President Obama to close the American military prison at Guantánamo Bay, consider the case of Alla Ali Bin Ali Ahmed, Internee Security No. 692. His long-delayed departure last week leaves 97 Yemenis at the complex in Cuba, by far the largest remaining group.

articles.headline: Hollywood Hotels Are Hubs for Deal Making

articles.headline: The Cost of Saving These Whales
articles.snippet: How the “too big to fail” policy for banks goes awry and hurts smaller, perhaps more responsible competitors.
articles.abstract: How the “too big to fail” policy for banks goes awry and hurts smaller, perhaps more responsible competitors.
articles.lead_paragraph: AMID all the talk about systemic risk regulators, consumer protection and other fixes to our fractured financial system, there is a troubling silence on what may be the single most important reform: how to rid ourselves of banks that are so big and interconnected that their very existence threatens the world.

articles.headline: Will Books Be Napsterized?
articles.snippet: As the hardware for electronic books moves closer to the mainstream, publishers wonder whether their industry can be spared the potential problems of piracy.
articles.abstract: As the hardware for electronic books moves closer to the mainstream, publishers wonder whether their industry can be spared the potential problems of piracy.
articles.lead_paragraph: YOU can buy “The Lost Symbol,” by Dan Brown, as an e-book for $9.99 at Amazon.com.

articles.headline: Report Says Iran Has Data to Make a Nuclear Bomb
articles.snippet: A U.N. analysis says Iran has “sufficient information to be able to design and produce a workable” bomb, going well beyond the public position taken by Washington.
articles.abstract: A U.N. analysis says Iran has “sufficient information to be able to design and produce a workable” bomb, going well beyond the public position taken by Washington.
articles.lead_paragraph: Senior staff members of the United Nations nuclear agency have concluded in a confidential analysis that Iran has acquired “sufficient information to be able to design and produce a workable” atom bomb.
articles.byline: By William J. Broad and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Attacks on Remote Posts Highlight Afghan Risks
articles.snippet: An attack that killed eight Americans underscored the vulnerability of the kind of isolated bases that the top American commander wants to scale back.
articles.abstract: An attack that killed eight Americans underscored the vulnerability of the kind of isolated bases that the top American commander wants to scale back.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan  Insurgents attacked a pair of remote American military bases in Afghanistan over the weekend in a deadly battle that underscored the vulnerability of the kind of isolated bases that the top American commander there wants to scale back.
articles.byline: By Sabrina Tavernise and Sangar Rahimi

articles.headline: China Yearns to Form Its Own Media Empires
articles.snippet: China plans to spend billions of dollars to develop media companies that it hopes can compete with the likes of News Corporation and Time Warner.
articles.abstract: China plans to spend billions of dollars to develop media companies that it hopes can compete with the likes of News Corporation and Time Warner.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI  China plans to spend billions of dollars in the next few years to develop media and entertainment companies that it hopes can compete with global giants like the News Corporation and Time Warner, and will in the process loosen some of its tight control of these industries.

articles.headline: Of Layoffs, Bankruptcy and Bonuses
articles.snippet: The Tribune Company wants to pay managers up to $66 million in bonuses, which would be the highest ever paid, even as the company struggles.
articles.abstract: The Tribune Company wants to pay managers up to $66 million in bonuses, which would be the highest ever paid, even as the company struggles.
articles.lead_paragraph: Let’s say that a group of corporate executives uses scads of debt to take over a struggling company, sells off some profitable assets, lays off thousands of employees while achieving miserable results. And then, less than a year after saddling the company with $8 billion in debt, they opt for bankruptcy.

articles.headline: Bonds Boom as Investors Flock Back
articles.snippet: Some analysts call the resurgence a sign that credit markets have recovered. Others warn that bond prices could roll backward if the economy stumbles.
articles.abstract: Some analysts call the resurgence a sign that credit markets have recovered. Others warn that bond prices could roll backward if the economy stumbles.
articles.lead_paragraph: The swift rally in stock markets this year caught everyone’s attention. But with far less fanfare, a frenzy has been taking place in the market for corporate bonds.

articles.abstract: A project at Google to offer more elaborate ads on high-end phones has hit one glitch after another.

articles.headline: Voice of Bush’s Favored General Is Now Harder to Hear
articles.snippet: Gen. David H. Petraeus faces a new reality in President Obama’s White House: He is still at the table, but in a very different seat.
articles.abstract: Gen. David H. Petraeus faces a new reality in President Obama’s White House: He is still at the table, but in a very different seat.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Gen. David H. Petraeus, the face of the Iraq troop surge and a favorite of former President George W. Bush, spoke up or was called upon by President Obama “several times” during the big Afghanistan strategy session in the Situation Room last week, one participant says, and will be back for two more meetings this week.

articles.headline: New Court Term May Give Hints to Views on Regulating Business
articles.snippet: The Supreme Court term that begins Monday will be dominated by cases concerning corporations, compensation and the financial markets.
articles.abstract: The Supreme Court term that begins Monday will be dominated by cases concerning corporations, compensation and the financial markets.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The new Supreme Court term that begins Monday will be dominated by cases concerning corporations, compensation and the financial markets that could signal the justices’ attitude toward regulatory constraints at a time of extraordinary government intervention in the economy.

articles.headline: Profits for Buyout Firms as Company Debt Soared

articles.abstract: Private equity firms, former executives and Wall Street investment banks profited as the Simmons Bedding Company fell into bankruptcy, devastating its bondholders and employees.
articles.lead_paragraph: For most of the 133 years since its founding in a small city in Wisconsin, the Simmons Bedding Company enjoyed an illustrious history.

articles.headline: To Protect Galápagos, Ecuador Limits a Two-Legged Species
articles.snippet: Officials have expelled poor migrants in an effort to preserve the natural wonders that bolster one of Ecuador’s most profitable sectors: tourism.
articles.abstract: Officials have expelled poor migrants in an effort to preserve the natural wonders that bolster one of Ecuador’s most profitable sectors: tourism.
articles.lead_paragraph: PUERTO AYORA, Galápagos Islands  The mounds of reeking garbage on the edge of this settlement 600 miles off Ecuador’s Pacific coast are proof that one species is thriving on the fragile archipelago whose unique wildlife inspired Darwin’s theory of evolution: man.
